purpose.summary: This policy establishes the framework for adapting the Company's US-based compensation plans to international jurisdictions. It mandates that all international compensation arrangements undergo local legal review and compliance verification before implementation, ensuring adherence to country-specific employment laws, tax regulations, data privacy requirements, and labor standards.
objectives: Establish framework for adapting US-based compensation plans to international jurisdictions
Mandate local legal review for all international compensation arrangements
Ensure adherence to country-specific employment laws and tax regulations
Comply with data privacy requirements and labor standards in each jurisdiction

appliesTo: All the Company sales compensation plans implemented outside the United States
All sales representatives employed in international markets
Expatriate assignments involving compensation plan administration
Third-party sales agents and representatives in foreign jurisdictions
All divisions and business units operating internationally

definitions.definition: The country where the Company maintains its primary legal entity and where the employee's employment contract originates.
The country where the employee physically works and where local employment laws apply.

Examination of compensation plan terms by qualified employment counsel licensed to practice law in the host country, specifically assessing compliance with local labor laws, tax regulations, and employment standards.

Compensation arrangement where portions of an employee's pay are processed through different country payrolls to manage tax obligations, social security contributions, and compliance requirements across jurisdictions.
The standard the Company US compensation plan structure (e.g., SCP-001 through SCP-016) used as the starting template for international adaptation.
Employee transferred from their home country to work in a host country, typically maintaining home-country employment contract with host-country supplements.
Employee hired directly in the host country under local employment contract and terms.
Employee from one country working in a second country for a company headquartered in a third country.

provisions.title: Policy Principles
provisions.content: Four core principles governing international compensation plan adaptation.

subProvisions.title: US Plans as Baseline Reference
subProvisions.content: All the Company international compensation plans shall use the corresponding US plan as the structural baseline, ensuring consistency in plan philosophy, alignment with corporate strategy, shared terminology, and streamlined administration.

subProvisions.title: Local Legal Review Mandatory
subProvisions.content: No exceptions. Every international compensation plan or plan modification must undergo review by qualified local employment counsel before implementation.

subProvisions.title: Compliance Over Consistency
subProvisions.content: When local law conflicts with US plan terms, local law always prevails. The Company prioritizes legal compliance over administrative convenience or global consistency.

subProvisions.title: Document All Adaptations
subProvisions.content: Every deviation from the US baseline plan must be:
items: Documented in writing
Approved by local legal counsel
Reviewed by Global HR and Finance
Maintained in the plan governance repository

provisions.title: Legal Review Requirements
provisions.content: When, who, and what must be included in local legal review.

subProvisions.title: When Legal Review is Required
subProvisions.content: Local legal review is mandatory for:
items: New Market Entry - Before implementing any compensation plan in a new country
Plan Changes - Any modification to existing international plan terms
Policy Adoptions - Applying any US policy (SCP-001 through SCP-016) internationally
Expatriate Assignments - Compensation arrangements for international transfers
Agent Agreements - Third-party sales representative contracts
Annual Compliance Check - Minimum once per year for active plans

subProvisions.title: Who Conducts the Review
subProvisions.content: Legal review must be performed by employment law counsel licensed in the host country, with expertise in local labor and employment law, tax and social security regulations, data privacy and GDPR (if applicable), and commercial agent regulations (if applicable).

subProvisions.title: What Must Be Reviewed
subProvisions.content: Legal counsel must assess:
items: Compensation Structure: commission methodologies, bonus eligibility, payment timing, currency, minimum wage compliance
Tax and Social Security: withholding requirements, social security contributions, cross-border tax, split payroll, tax equalization
Termination and Final Pay: notice periods, severance, commission on termination, garden leave, non-compete enforceability
Data Privacy: GDPR compliance, employee data collection, cross-border data transfers, consent, retention obligations
Worker Classification: employee vs contractor status, commission-only arrangements, agency relationships, co-employment risks
Contractual Terms: employment contract requirements, mandatory benefits, works council notification, language requirements

subProvisions.title: Documentation Standards
subProvisions.content: Legal review deliverables must include:
items: Written opinion letter from counsel
Redlined plan document showing required changes
List of local law conflicts with US baseline
Risk assessment and mitigation strategies
Approval signatures from local legal counsel, Country HR Director, Global HR leadership, and Finance/Tax department

provisions.title: Key Compliance Areas
provisions.content: Critical areas requiring adaptation when implementing compensation plans internationally.

subProvisions.title: Tax Withholding and Social Security
subProvisions.content: Each country has unique tax withholding tables and schedules. Social security contributions vary. Totalization agreements may reduce double-taxation. Exchange rate management required for multi-currency arrangements.

subProvisions.title: Worker Classification
subProvisions.content: Misclassification penalties can be severe. Tests vary by country. Commission-only arrangements may trigger employee status. Agency laws differ significantly (especially in EU).

subProvisions.title: GDPR and Data Privacy
subProvisions.content: Key requirements for EU/EEA operations:
items: Lawful basis for processing employee data
Data minimization - collect only necessary information
Employee consent for non-essential data collection
Data subject rights (access, correction, deletion)
Cross-border data transfer restrictions
Data breach notification obligations

subProvisions.title: Commission Payment Timing
subProvisions.content: Many countries mandate specific payment deadlines. Delays can trigger penalties and interest obligations. 'Reasonably prompt' may be defined by statute (e.g., 30 days).

subProvisions.title: Termination Rights (EU Commercial Agents Directive)
subProvisions.content: Key requirements for EU/EEA:
items: Minimum notice periods: 1 month (Year 1), 2 months (Year 2), 3 months (Year 3+)
Termination indemnity or compensation required (typically 6-24 months of average annual compensation)
Cannot be waived by contract choice-of-law clause
Applies to independent sales agents, not employees (but definitions vary)

subProvisions.title: Notice Periods and Severance
subProvisions.content: Statutory notice periods often longer than US standards. Severance pay may be mandatory. Garden leave common in some jurisdictions.

subProvisions.title: Final Pay and Commission on Termination
subProvisions.content: Many countries require immediate or near-immediate final pay. Commission on pending deals may be required by law. Clawback provisions may be restricted or prohibited.

provisions.title: Adaptation Process
provisions.content: Five-step process for adapting US plans to international jurisdictions.

subProvisions.title: Five-Step Process
subProvisions.content: Required steps for international plan adaptation:
items: Step 1: Select US Plan as Template - Identify the relevant US baseline policy
Step 2: Identify Local Requirements - Engage local counsel to review baseline and categorize provisions as conflicting, risky, administrative differences, or acceptable
Step 3: Document Required Changes - Redline the US plan, add explanatory notes, include legal citations, flag areas for ongoing monitoring
Step 4: Obtain Approvals - From local legal counsel, Country HR Director, Global HR Corporate, Finance/Tax, and SGCC
Step 5: Implement with Local HR - Translate documents if required, obtain acknowledgments, notify works council, update payroll, train managers, monitor compliance

provisions.title: Country-Specific Considerations
provisions.content: Key requirements for major regions and cross-references to affected policies.

subProvisions.title: European Union / EEA
subProvisions.content: Applies to all EU Member States plus Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway:
items: EU Commercial Agents Directive: minimum notice periods, termination indemnity rights (cannot be waived)
GDPR: Strict data privacy requirements
Works Councils: Notification/consultation may be required (especially Germany, Netherlands, France)
Posted Workers Directive: Applies to employees temporarily working in another EU country

subProvisions.title: United Kingdom (Post-Brexit)
subProvisions.content: Key UK-specific requirements:
items: Commercial Agents Regulations 1993 still in force (mirrors EU Directive)
Statutory notice period minimums apply
IR35 Rules: Complex contractor vs employee tests
Restrictive covenants enforceable but must be reasonable

subProvisions.title: Canada
subProvisions.content: Employment law is provincial (not federal):
items: Notice period or pay in lieu (varies by province)
No at-will employment
Quebec: French language requirements for employment documents
Different rules in Alberta, Ontario, British Columbia, etc.

subProvisions.title: Australia / New Zealand
subProvisions.content: Key APAC requirements:
items: Fair Work Act (Australia): National employment standards
Minimum Award wages: Industry-specific minimums
Superannuation (pension) contributions mandatory
Unfair dismissal protections
Good faith bargaining obligations (New Zealand)

subProvisions.title: Latin America
subProvisions.content: Strong labor protections (employee-favorable):
items: Mandatory 13th/14th month salary common
Profit-sharing requirements (e.g., Mexico)
Severance formulas often statutory
Extremely difficult to terminate employees (e.g., Brazil)

subProvisions.title: Asia Pacific
subProvisions.content: Varies dramatically by country:
items: Japan: Lifetime employment culture, difficult terminations
Singapore: Employment Act, Foreign Worker Quotas
India: State-specific labor laws, provident fund
China: Labor Contract Law, severance calculations, FESCO arrangements
Hong Kong: Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF)

provisions.title: Prohibited Practices
provisions.content: Practices strictly prohibited without local legal approval.

subProvisions.title: Prohibited Actions
subProvisions.content: The following are strictly prohibited without local legal approval:
items: Applying US-only legal references (Section 409A, FLSA, US state wage laws) in non-US plans
Ignoring mandatory local benefits (statutory pension/social security, 13th month salary, works council notification)
Inadequate data protection (transferring EU data to US without legal basis, processing without consent, failing to honor data subject requests)
Misclassifying workers (treating employees as contractors, commission-only arrangements triggering employee status, sham agency relationships)
Unenforceable clawback provisions (clawing back legally-earned commissions, applying prohibited clawbacks, withholding final pay where prohibited)
Insufficient notice periods (applying US at-will termination, notice shorter than statutory minimum, failing to pay in lieu)
At-will employment language in international contracts

provisions.title: Documentation and Audit
provisions.content: Requirements for maintaining local plan variants, legal review sign-offs, annual compliance audit, and change management.

subProvisions.title: Local Plan Variants
subProvisions.content: For each country, maintain:
items: Plan Document: Full plan text with local adaptations
Legal Opinion: Counsel's review and approval
Redline Comparison: US baseline vs local version
Translation: If required by local law
Employee Acknowledgments: Signed receipt of plan
Works Council Notification: If applicable

subProvisions.title: Annual Compliance Audit
subProvisions.content: Conduct annual review:
items: Have local laws changed?
Are plan terms still compliant?
Do translations need updating?
Have exchange rates affected compensation levels?
Are payment deadlines being met?

subProvisions.title: Change Management Process
subProvisions.content: When US baseline plans change:
items: Assess impact on international plans
Determine if local changes required
Engage local counsel for review
Update local plan documents
Notify affected employees
Update training materials

provisions.title: Governance
provisions.content: Policy ownership, approval authority, review frequency, and exception process.

subProvisions.title: Approval Authority
subProvisions.content: Approval requirements by action type:
items: New Country Entry: Global CHRO + General Counsel
Plan Changes: Country HR Director + Local Counsel + Global HR
Exceptions: Global CHRO

subProvisions.title: Review Frequency
subProvisions.content: Annual review of all active international plans. Event-driven review when entering new country, changing US baseline plans, local laws change, or compliance issues arise.

subProvisions.title: Exception Process
subProvisions.content: Exceptions require:
items: Global CHRO approval
Documented risk assessment
Elevated legal review and sign-off
Subject to additional audit scrutiny
